page.title: 07FARMING, LAND TENURE
page.content: The great majority of farms are occupied by their owners and, indeed, a few of them have remained in the same family since the mid-nineteenth century or even earlier. A particular feature of this area is the extensive tract of land which was formerly part of FFOREST FAWR - the Great Forest of Brecknock - which had been a Crown Estate until the early nineteenth century. Through long usage, those farming adjacent enclosed land has acquired grazing rights on the Great Forest,together with certain other rights, notably that to work limestone on the outcrops of Carbon- iferous Limestone in the upper Tawe valley.In 1819 an Enclosure Act alloc -ated a large part of the land to the Crown, this depriving other farms in the area of their grazing rights. The land was known as the CROWN ALLOTMENT.
